I just thought I'd follow up on some of Ian's comments based on my
experience in the US.  

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> At 14:01 24/05/2005, you wrote:
> >Thanks so much for your input guys, it is GREATLY appreciated. 
I've
> >been re-reading your posts several times now, exploring the
Internet
> >for information on Unis and thinking long and hard about my future.
> >After all this, besides getting a headache, I have come up with a
few
> >key points:
> >
> >(1) I don't know if I'm "qualified" to enter into a PhD programme
at
> >the moment.  More than anything else this is because I am not
really
> >sure what's involved in getting accepted.  I find that concrete
> >information can be difficult to find on Universities' websites. 
From
> >my limited exposure to the entry requirements, I have noticed that
> >applicants are required to write comprehensive essays and give
> >discussions on their interested topic, including its history.  I do
> >feel that my enthusiasm is at about 1000%, after engrossing myself
in
> >the subject for the last year, but I don't know if I'd live up to
the
> >PhD entry standards.
> 
> Generally a good BSc is all that's required on paper and the rest is
down 
> to impressing the potential-supervisor when you speak to him/her...
> 
> Enthusiasm will help a lot, as will having already worked in a
related area.
> 

This is absolutely right.  It is a misconception to think that any
department expects you to be an expert before you arrive.  In my
opinion at least, raw creative ability is far more valuable than 
expansive expertise, which can be picked up sooner or later. 
Enthusiasm is a great predictor as well.

> >Furthermore, correct me if I'm wrong, but it seems that if I'm
> >interested in pursuing a PhD at a particular University, it is on
me
> >to: (a) come up with a project idea, (b) email the appropriate
person,
> >(c) convince them to fund me while I do the work at their
institution.
> >  While I certainly have the enthusiasm and the drive to accomplish
> >such a feat, I wonder if I would be successful after only 0.5
years of
> >experience in the subject itself.  I find it difficult to know who
> >exactly to ask in a Uni such specific questions and I don't want to
> >bother the department heads if I don't need to.
> 
> I hesitate to answer, because clearly a few things have changed
since my 
> time as a Ph.D. student.
> 
> Generally, however, this picture you paint seems a bit backwards. 
Usually 
> what will happen (used to happen) is that a supervisor will have
funding 
> for a Ph.D. place and will look around for somebody to fill it.  You
are at 
> a disadvantage compared to people who already did their first
degree in 
> that department, simply because they will be known to the supervisor
and 
> also first to hear of it.

This may be true in some places, but it is probably not true as a
general rule.  A lot of places discourage students from applying to
the same place they completed they undergrad degree.  I know that the
opposite also occurs, but opinions are very mixed.  UPenn told me
personally when I was an undergrad there I probably should apply
elsewhere.  That may reflect on me (I hope not!) but I think it was
more of a general philosophy that it's healthier for everyone not to
be recycling the same blood forever.  Therefore, I'd say being an
outsider is just as likely to be an advantage as a disadvantage.  

Also, admission rationale can vary widely.  In some big departments,
they admit a lot of people who don't fit in with any specific funded
research just because the person sounds promising or may fit in in the
future.  UT is like that.  I came in as a TA with no official tie to
any advisor.  They expected people like me to look for an advisor in
the couple years following admission to the Ph.D. program.  So the
point is, no prior tie-in was necessary.

> 
> The subject of the Ph.D. is usually worked out by interaction
between you 
> and the supervisor, and generally changes a bit over the course of
the 
> first year (mine went from enzyme kinetics and genetic engineering
to 
> computer simulation -- at one point I was just going to entitle it 
> "Studies." :) ).  How much of the subject is you and how much is
the 
> supervisor depends on how the two of you get on.  You do here of
people 
> studying something completely against the supervisors will, but a
lot 
> depends on who "owns" the funding, e.g. a studentship is generally
awarded 
> to _you_ and in extreme cases can be transferred to another
supervisor, 
> whereas a research-assistantship is generally awarded to the
supervisor...
> 

This is no doubt true in some places but again in other places the
department can support you for years without any definitive research
agenda or even advisor.  It just depends on the department.  (perhaps
it is also related to the academic culture in different countries)

> Half a years experience is a little low, but generally you learn
what you 
> need for a Ph.D. during the Ph.D. itself, e.g. my undergraduate 
> Biochemistry merely equipped me to _start_ learning thew techniques
I 
> needed for a Ph.D. in enzyme kinetics, and when I switched to a 
> computer-based approach I was essentially making it up myself....
> 
> >(2) Unfortunately, as I'm sure you can all tell, this whole
process is
> >being rushed quite severely as I would like to continue studying
ASAP
> >and not take too long of a break in between.  Of course, I need to
> >balance this with finding the right institution, which may prove
> >difficult.  That being said, it appears that most of the North
> >American Universities stopped accepting MSc applications several
> >months ago.
> 
> In the UK, at least, Ph.Ds don't start at any particular time of 
> year.  Although they cluster around september, just because that's
when all 
> the recent graduates get back from their holidays.  M.Sc.s come in
two 
> flavours "by research" and "taught".  The former is 1/3 of a Ph.D,
whereas 
> the latter is like an extra year of your B.Sc. course -- with the
exception 
> that it will specialize a lot more.
> 

It's probably better to check the admissions schedules of the specific
universities you are interested in rather than generalizing by county
or continent.

> >(3) Does anyone know of any Universities in Canada that are doing
work
> >in the fields being discussed here?  I've looked myself and come up
> >empty handed.  I've also emailed the CompSci departments at
Waterloo
> >and UofT to get their opinion, but have yet to hear back.
> 
> Sorry, no idea.  You do have the biggest computer-game company in
the world 
> however... and I think they sponsor a certain amount of research.
> 
> >(4) Right, more opinions needed.  I'll be honest, I'm VERY keen to
do
> >a PhD at UCF once Ken gets settled and gets the department up and
> >running.
> 
> 25 years time then...
> 
> <ducks>
> 
> But seriously, getting anything solid started in academia can take
ages...
> 

:) How can I avoid responding to this?  This kind of thing can't be
predicted but I've seen people launch big research programs in their
first year before.  It depends on your connections and your startup
package terms.  Also, the department can support students through
TAships who are starting out who will eventually convert to RAships
when the professor gets things rolling.  One thing I can tell you is
that American Universities try to encourage the young profs to get
things off the ground quickly.  I have a startup package that includes
a certain level of funding for an RA and research costs right off the
bat.  Ian's right though that establishing a big thriving research
group will take time, but in general the first people to show up will
be the ones who end up in that research group.  Keep in mind I was a
TA for 2 or 3 years here at UT before my advisor (Risto) paid me a
penny out of his research budget.  Nevertheless, I was gradually
establishing myself as a member of his group during that time, and
getting paid the whole time by the department's TA fund.  At UT at
least, that seems to be the norm: People spend the first few years as
a TA while they shop around for an advisor.  Advisors start paying
people once they've become established and productive in research.
Obviously the timetable can vary a lot since some people know exactly
what they want to do and some have no idea.

> >   In the mean time, the University of Sussex's "Evolutionary
> >and Adaptive Systems' MSc programme looks absolutely perfect for
where
> >I am right now.  My thinking is that the extra year of intensive NE
> >work should provide me with a more thorough background in NE (and
> >related subjects) and thus perhaps get me into these surely
> >competitive programmes.  What do you guys think?  Is that overkill
or
> >does it seem like a reasonable plan?
> 
> Presumably you have confirmed that NE is in this program and that at
least 
> one staff member is keen on it?
> 
> e.g. "Evolutionary and Adaptive Systems' doesn't _have_ to include
any NE, 
> and if it does may not include TWEAN and only focus on tweaking 
> weights.  It depends on the staff involved.  e.g. what they teach
you will 
> focus on their personal interests, surrounded by a halo of more
general 
> stuff, but if they personally dislike some approach, it can be
reduced to a 
> mere footnote.
> 

There are a few people who were on this group that actually took that
program.  I wonder if any of them could comment...

> Other than that, it sounds excellent and if you can get money from 
> somewhere, it would be a very good set up for a Ph.D. plus giving
you a 
> year to find one...
> 

That's true, it may be a good way to spend the intervening year.

> Best of luck and hope I'm not lying.
> 
> 
>          Ian
> 
> p.s. there must be resources to help you with this, web-sites, 
> careers-advisors, people you know from your last course...
> 

Also some people on this group have been through looking for a program
before.  It's tough in North America since hardly anywhere has any
TWEANN or AE research going on.  There are a ton of programs ranked
highly in AI, but for some reason they aren't doing the stuff we're
interested in.  In some ways, we are in a battle to get established on
this continent because the  AI people in the more dominant/older areas
are essentially a self-perpetuating unit.  But that's always the case
with change.

ken
